The types of physical samples that are used to undertake quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC) checks at all stages of the sampling, preparation and analytical processes, and/or to retain representative material for future reference. Note that QA and QC are often used collectively as a single term, but are in fact distinct procedures: QA 'refers to defect prevention', i.e. ‘the protocols and procedures that ensure that sampling and assaying is completed to the required quality’, whereas QC 'refers to defect detection', i.e. ‘the use of control samples and statistical analysis to ensure that assay results are reliable’ (Graindorge, 2010, p. 112; https://www.usgs.gov/data-management/manage-quality). This vocabulary thus also encapsulates terminology covering sample representability.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A certified reference material (CRM) is a sample material that has been prepared, typically in commercial volumes, and characterised by analysis across multiple laboratories (sometimes called 'round-robin certification'). The values for CRMs are generally well-known published figures. Elements and isotope ratios that have been characterised in this process are attributed with a certified value and uncertainty, specific to a certain analytical technique. CRMs are used to monitor accuracy and bias at the project laboratory relative to the certified values. They are also used to monitor drift over time within an individual laboratory and to identify significant failures in QC at the analytical batch level caused by abrupt changes in concentration related to re-calibration of instruments or procedural changes at the laboratory. CRMs can also be used to verify new or improved analytical techniques.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition modified from Smee et al. (2024) and Geoscience Australia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A certified reference material (CRM) is a sample material that has been prepared, typically in commercial volumes, and characterised by analysis across multiple laboratories (sometimes called 'round-robin certification'). The values for CRMs are generally well-known published figures. Elements and isotope ratios that have been characterised in this process are attributed with a certified value and uncertainty, specific to a certain analytical technique. CRMs are used to monitor accuracy and bias at the project laboratory relative to the certified values. They are also used to monitor drift over time within an individual laboratory and to identify significant failures in QC at the analytical batch level caused by abrupt changes in concentration related to re-calibration of instruments or procedural changes at the laboratory. CRMs can also be used to verify new or improved analytical techniques.

Also known as SRM,  these samples may range from International Standards and Certified Reference Materials (CRMs) to locally prepared standard samples for use as project reference standards. They are comprised of homogenous material prepared under strict guidelines, divided into numerous aliquots and sent to reputable laboratories to derive an assigned value. The values for Standard Reference Materials are generally well known published figures. SRMs with certified values are used to calibrate instruments or analytical techniques, to quantify analytical accuracy, and to verify new or improved analytical techniques. The material of the reference standard (eg, rock, mineral, water, etc) should be denoted in "material type".
A profile for SKOS Concept Schemes
